title: 107_s3097
content: The Act is titled the "Maximum Economic Growth for America Through Innovative Finance Act or MEGA Innovate." It introduces a nonrefundable credit for holders of qualified highway bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Maximum Economic Growth for America Through Innovative Finance Act or MEGA Innovate" introduces a nonrefundable credit for holders of qualified highway bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Taxpayers holding qualified highway bonds on credit allowance dates during the taxable year can claim a credit against the tax imposed, calculated as 25 percent of the annual credit determined for the bond. The applicable credit rate for qualified highway bonds is determined by multiplying the rate by the outstanding face amount of the bond. The credit allowance date is specified as March 15, June 15, September 15, and December 15, including the last day the bond is outstanding. The credit for qualified highway bonds is based on the outstanding face amount of the bond. A special rule applies for bonds issued or redeemed within a 3-month period ending on a credit allowance date. The credit allowed for any taxable year is limited by the excess of the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55 over the sum of the credits allowable under this. The credit for qualified highway bonds allows for carryover of unused credit to the next taxable year. Gross income includes the credit allowed to the taxpayer and is treated as interest income. A qualified highway bond is defined as a bond where 95% or more of the proceeds are transferred to the Highway Trust Fund. The Highway Trust Fund receives funds from qualified highway bonds issued by the Secretary, with specific requirements such as a 20-year term and a maximum issuance limit. The Secretary is limited to issuing $3 billion for 2004-2008 and $1 billion for 2009. The text discusses definitions and rules related to bonds, partnerships, and other pass-thru entities for the purpose of a tax credit. It also mentions procedures for allowing the credit to shareholders of regulated investment companies holding qualified highway bonds. Amendments to reporting requirements under section 6049 of the Internal Revenue Code are also mentioned. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include reporting requirements for credit on qualified highway bonds, treating certain amounts as paid on the credit allowance date. The Secretary is granted regulatory authority in this matter. The Secretary has regulatory authority to prescribe necessary regulations for reporting requirements on credit for qualified highway bonds. The credit allowed by section 54 for holding a qualified highway bond is treated as a payment of estimated tax. The credit allowed for holding a qualified highway bond is treated as a payment of estimated tax on the credit allowance date. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to transfer proceeds from qualified highway bonds to the Highway Trust Fund. This includes a conforming amendment to subsection (b) of section 9503 and a clerical amendment to the table of subparts for part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments for the Nonrefundable Credit for Holders of Qualified Highway Bonds apply to obligations issued after December 31, 2003.
